{{Korean name|[[Shin (Korean name)|Shin]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Shin Kyuk-ho | image = | image_caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1922|10|8}} | birth_place = [[Ulsan]], [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese Korea]]
{{small|(now Ulsan, South Korea)}} | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Founder of [[Lotte Corporation]] | education = [[Waseda University]] | networth = 270.5 billion [[South Korean won|won]] (2016){{citenews|url=http://www.asiaone.com/business/look-5-richest-conglomerate-families-south-korea|title=A look at 5 richest conglomerate families in South Korea|work=The Korea Herald|date=2016-12-23|access-date=2018-08-15}} | spouse = Noh Soon-hwa (m. 1942-1951)
Hatsuko Shigemitsu (m. 1952)
Seo Mi-kyung | partner = | children = 4 | awards = }} {{Infobox East Asian |title=Native names |hangul=신격호 |hanja=辛格浩 |rr=Sin Gyeok-ho |mr=Sin Kyŏkho |kanji=重光 武雄 |hepburn=Shigemitsu Takeo }} '''Shin Kyuk-ho''' (born 8 October 1922), known in Japan as '''Takeo Shigemitsu''',{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/lotte-group-founder-shin-kyuk-hos-life-from-rags-to-riches-to-prison-term|title=Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk Ho's life from rags to riches to prison term|last=|first=|date=2017-12-22|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-08-15|language=en}} is a South Korean businessman and founder of the Korean conglomerate [[Lotte Corporation]].{{Cite web|url=http://100.daum.net/encyclopedia/view/b13s2471a|title=신격호|last=|first=|date=|website=Daum 100|language=ko|trans-title=Shin Kyuk-ho|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15}} == Career == Shin was born in [[Ulsan]], [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese Korea]] in 1922. In 1941, he stowed away on a ship to Japan, where he studied chemical engineering at [[Waseda University]]. He adopted the Japanese name Takeo Shigemitsu and opened a [[rice cooker]] manufacturing plant in 1942. After the plant was destroyed during an [[Air raids on Japan|air raid]], Shin founded [[Lotte (conglomerate)|Lotte]] in 1948, which grew from selling chewing gum to becoming a major [[multinational corporation]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/03/03/national/media-national/anniversaries-loom-gum-producer-lotte-yoshiwara-red-light-district/|title=Anniversaries loom for gum producer Lotte and the Yoshiwara red-light district|last=Schreiber|first=Mark|date=2018-03-03|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-08-15|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}} In 2006, Shin and his family were ranked 136th on ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine's list, "[[The World's Billionaires]]."{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/business/lists/2006/10/K7A2.html|title=#136 Shin Kyuk-Ho & family|last=|first=|date=2006|website=Forbes|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15}} In 2009, Shin was ranked 38th on the magazine's list of South Korea's richest people.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/83/korea-rich-09_Shin-Kyuk-Ho_K7A2.html|title=#38 Shin Kyuk-Ho|last=|first=|date=2009-04-29|website=Forbes|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15}} Lotte itself was [[South Korea]]'s fifth largest [[Chaebol|conglomerate]] as of 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/business/2017/08/01/27/0501000000AEN20170801007900320F.html|title=Lotte Hotel to open chain in Myanmar next month|last=|first=|date=2017-08-01|work=Yonhap News Agency|access-date=2018-08-15|language=en}} In June 2017, Shin retired from his role as board director of Lotte Holdings Co. after holding the position for nearly 70 years.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-24/lotte-group-founder-shin-kyuk-ho-retires-as-board-director-at-94|title=Lotte Group Founder Shin Kyuk-ho Retires as Board Director at 94|last=Kim|first=Hooyeon|date=2017-06-24|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15|subscription=yes}} In December 2017, he was sentenced to four years in prison after he was convicted of embezzling 128.6 billion [[South Korean won|won]] (119 million [[United States dollar|USD]]) from Lotte. However, Shin was allowed to remain free given his poor health.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-42451425|title=Jail for 95-year-old South Korean tycoon|last=|first=|date=2017-12-22|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-08-15|language=en-GB}} ==Personal life== Shin has a total of four children from three marriages. His first wife, Noh Soon-hwa, died in 1951. They have one daughter, Shin Young-ja (born 1942).{{Cite web|url=http://www.munhwa.com/news/view.html?no=2016070701071030123001&w=nl|title=신영자 이사장 영장심사때 대성통곡… '애끓는 모정'|last=Min|first=Byeong-ki|last2=Park|first2=Jun-u|date=2016-07-07|website=Munhwa Ilbo|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15}} Shin then married a Japanese woman, Hatsuko Shigemitsu, in 1952.{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.kr/2015/08/01/story_n_7916268.html|title=롯데, 시게미쓰 家門의 전쟁|last=Yu|first=Sin-jae|date=2015-08-01|work=The Dong-joo|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15}} and [[Shin Dong-bin]] (born 1955).{{Cite web|url=http://100.daum.net/encyclopedia/view/33XXXXX20533|title=신동빈|last=|first=|date=|website=Daum 100|language=ko|trans-title=Shin Dong-bin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-15}} Shin is also married to Seo Mi-Kyung in South Korea under the country's [[common-law marriage]] system.{{Cite News Agency|access-date=2018-08-15|language=en}} They have one daughter, Shin Yu-mi (born 1983).{{Cite news|url=http://biz.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2015/08/27/2015082702392.html|title=롯데가 경영권 분쟁 {{Multiple issues| {{BLP refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{More footnotes|date=December 2015}}}} {{Infobox person | name = Stanko Subotić | image = Stanko Subotic Cane.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1959|09|09}} | birth_place = [[Kalinovac (Ub)|Kalinovac]], [[People's Republic of Serbia|PR Serbia]], [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|FPR Yugoslavia]] | occupation = Entrepreneur
Owner of [[D Trade]], Futura Plus, Famis LLC | networth = | spouse = Jagoda | children = 1 | residence = [[Geneva, Switzerland]] | website = http://www.stanko-subotic.com | signature = Cane signature.jpg }} '''Stanko "Cane" Subotić''' (born 9 September 1959, [[Kalinovac (Ub)|Kalinovac]], [[People's Republic of Serbia|PR Serbia]], [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|FPR Yugoslavia]]) is a [[Geneva]]-based Serbian businessman. He was sentenced to six years imprisonment for abuse of office,{{clarify|date=January 2016}} but the case is on appeal. Subotić is the founder and owner of the [[Denmark]]-based company EMI (Emerging Marketing Investment) and [[D Trade]] (based in Belgrade, Serbia), dealing in sales and distribution of wine, paper and real estate. Additionally, he is the co-owner of Serbia-based [[Futura Plus]], a commercial distribution network in Southeastern Europe. In Serbia, his companies employ over 4,000 people.{{citation needed|date=November 2007}} Additionally, Subotić is the co-owner of the meat processing factory Famis LLC (founded in 2002 in Serbia), as well as distribution companies in [[Greece]] and [[Russia]] dealing in non-alcoholic beverages and sporting equipment. Moreover, he bought hundreds of acres of vineyards in [[France]], which he uses for production of the wine Louis Max, which has been served at the [[White House]].[http://www.b92.net/info/emisije/insajder.php?yyyy=2006&mm=05&nav_id=197780] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060522054819/http://www.b92.net/info/emisije/insajder.php?yyyy=2006&mm=05&nav_id=197780 |date=22 May 2006 }} He began investing in this company in 1989, and since January 2007 he is the sole owner of Max Holding. Subotić owns a wine cellar in downtown [[Belgrade]] and the luxury hotel Villa Montenegro on [[Sveti Stefan]] island. In March 2007, this hotel was awarded the "Five Stars Diamond" award for the quality of service by the [[American Academy of Hospitality Sciences]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ==Early life and business career== Subotić came from a working-class family, to which he was born as the sixth and youngest child. During early childhood, he started working in his father's carpentry shop. A Serbian national by birth, since 1999 He completed the streamlined High School of Economics in [[Ub, Serbia|Ub]], where he met his future wife Jagoda. He started earning an independent living in his early twenties when he left for [[France]] and got a job as a tailor. He opened a chain of clothing boutiques, and developed his own wholesale and retail.{{citation needed|date=August 2007}} During mid-1980s he invested into Serbian economy, by supplying civil engineering equipment which he judged to be in short supply. Subotić started his private business career in 1991 following the collapse of communism in [[SFR Yugoslavia]] by founding a company named MIA and opening a sewing shop that cooperated with state owned [[retailer]] [[Robna kuća Beograd|Robne kuće Beograd]]. From that time until the year 1993, his primary business activities were textile production and confection.{{cn|date=December 2015}} By 1995, he entered the cigarette trade in [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], a country under a [[United Nations|UN]] imposed [[trade embargo]]. Subotić owned two duty-free shops at the Đeneral Janković border crossing and in 1996 became exclusive distributor of foreign cigarette producers such as [[Philip Morris International|Philip Morris]] and [[British American Tobacco]]. His cigarette trading business was initially based in Serbia, but, in 1997, after Vlada "Tref" Kovačević and Radovan "Badža" Stojičić were murdered, Subotić relocated his entire business to [[Montenegro]] and moved there, where he established high political and business connections with the republic's Prime Minister [[Milo Đukanović]] and ruling [[Democratic Party of Socialists of Montenegro|DPS]] party president [[Svetozar Marović]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.co.rs/temadana.php?id=5486|title=Mira i Marko predvodili jednu od mafijaških grupa|website=Blic.co.rs|date=9 June 2007|accessdate=16 January 2016}} In 2003, Subotić opened a subsidiary in Montenegro, which is in operation to this day. The same year, he acquired the Serbian company [[Duvan]], owner of a large distribution network which included retail booths and kiosks selling printed media and other consumer goods, and founded the company [[Futura plus]]. After acquiring Duvan, in 2004, he began collaborating with the German media holding group [[WAZ-Mediengruppe|WAZ]], which brought him new points of sale as it acquired a majority stake at [[Politika AD|Politika distribution]]. Futura Plus now owns the largest media distribution network in Serbia with a large number of kiosks and newspaper stands, previously owned by Duvan, Politika distribution, [[Borba (newspaper)|Borba distribution]] and [[Duvanpromet]] from [[Kragujevac]]. After Serbian Prosecution raised accusations against Subotic in 2008, WAZ Media Group left Futura plus.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/srbija.php?yyyy=2008&mm=05&dd=08&nav_id=297516|title=VAC prodao udeo u "Futuri plus"|website=B92.net|date=8 May 2008|accessdate=16 January 2016}} In Montenegro he founded a company named Montenegro Futura that owns a similar distribution network throughout the country.{{cn|date=December 2015}} In 2005, Subotić moved his business headquarters to [[Cyprus]]. During the Spring 2007, Subotić additionally expanded his activities with two large investments in Montenegro: purchasing a piece of the island of St Nikola near the port of [[Budva]] from a Serbian businessman, Nenad Đorđević, for approximately [[€]]24 million and announcing his plans to build a luxury hotel worth [[€]]20 million on the St. Stefan island.[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/story.php?vest=52391] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927010608/http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/story.php?vest=52391 |date=27 September 2007 }} ==Controversy== Throughout the 2000s and 2010s, Subotić faced numerous allegations and accusations of smuggling, tax evasion, and state budget defrauding stemming from 1990s cigarette trade in the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] that was under a UN trade embargo at the time.{{cn|date=December 2015}} ===The ''Nacional'' affair=== In May 2001, Croatia's ''[[Nacional (weekly)|Nacional]]'' newsmagazine, owned and edited by [[Ivo Pukanić]], published detailed accounts of Subotić's activities, claiming they involved organized crime figures as well as the highest echelons of the Montenegrin and Serbian political regimes. Largely unknown and unexposed up to that point, the entire ''Nacional'' affair forced Subotić into the public limelight as he began giving occasional interviews in the Serbian media. He responded that the news stories were fabrications paid for and planted by a competing Croatian tobacco producer, [[Tvornica duhana Rovinj]], supposedly threatened by Subotić's plans to jointly build a tobacco factory in Serbia with British American Tobacco in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs/arhiva/2003/01/10/pisma/srpski/pisma.shtml|title=Stanko Subotić Cane: Moj deo istine|website=Arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs|accessdate=16 January 2016}} Over the coming years, Subotić filed a series of lawsuits against ''Nacional'' and its owner/editor-in-chief Pukanić in [[Zagreb]] on the grounds of slander. In Croatia, Subotić was represented by a Croatian lawyer, Slobodan Budak. ''Nacional'' claimed that "Subotić lost each one of the 26 lawsuits he filed against the magazine", while Subotić's lawyer in Serbia, Vlado Pavićević, claimed his client has "at least nine court verdicts in his favour".{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Hronika/t31491.sr.html|title=Политика Online|website=Politika.rs|accessdate=16 January 2016}} ===2006 ''Insajder'' interview=== In mid 2006, Subotić was hit with a new series of accusations when findings of the 2003 Serbian police investigation (soubriquetted "Mreža") were obtained by several media outlets, including [[B92]]. In it, Subotić's involvement in cigarette trade between 1995 and 1999 is characterized as "smuggling without taxation made possible by high ranking members of [[Slobodan Milošević|Milošević]]'s regime". On 15 May 2006, Subotić's taped interview with journalist [[Brankica Stanković]] aired on B92's ''[[Insajder]]'' programme. In it he claimed to have been shown the results of "Mreža" investigation way back in 2003 by then Serbian Interior Minister [[Dušan Mihajlović (politician)|Dušan Mihajlović]]. Subotić added that Mihajlović reassured him on the same occasion that he (Subotić) is not in any way subject of investigation, telling him that "your (Subotić's) business activities during the 1990s were found to be legit".{{cn|date=January 2016}} ===2007 'Mreža' arrests and Interpol arrest warrant=== On 6 June 2007 Serbian police arrested eight individuals, which it believes were part of a 15-person criminal group organized by Subotić. Subotić himself was not placed under arrest that day, because the police could not find him, however, an [[Interpol]] arrest warrant was later issued for him. The arrested individuals were placed in a 48-hour detention, and they include: *Milan Popivoda, former chief of Novi Sad state security branch *Miodrag Zavišić, former chief of Novi Sad police department *Nebojša "Tarzan" Nikolić and Drage Dodeski, former federal customs bureau employees *Milan "Mrgud" Milanović, former employee of different federal bodies and a prominent member of Škorpioni paramilitary unit. Since 2002 co-owner of Famis d.o.o. meat factory with Subotić{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Hronika/t30687.sr.html|title=Политика Online|website=Politika.rs|accessdate=16 January 2016}} *Milan "Pekin" Ranković, an employee in Subotić's MIA company *Ivana Olujić, accused of acting as a proxy in cigarette smuggling *Miroslav "Miki" Pešić, accused of making payments on behalf of Subotić's MIA company. On the same day, the [[Serbian Ministry of the Interior]] (MUP) issued a press release saying: "These arrests occurred following a detailed and thorough investigation taking place over several years in collaboration with special persecutor's office in regard to "Mreža" investigation. Subotić's group is being accused of illegally importing cigarettes and selling them on the [[black market]]. By doing so they defrauded the state budget of [[Deutsche Mark|DM]]80 million in unpaid tax. The money they made in Serbia was transferred to their accounts in [[Cyprus]] via [[Montenegro]] and [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]".[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/text.php?vest=59522] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608104436/http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/text.php?vest=59522 |date=8 June 2007 }} In addition to Subotić, six other individuals were sought by police on the same occasion: Ivan Krčmaričić, Đorđe Subotić, Luka Nenadić, Jovica Ranđelović, Stevan Banović, and Nikola Milošević (Subotić's nephew). Subotić eventually responded to the charges through a press release forwarded to Montenegrin state news agency MINA on 26 June 2007. He claimed innocence adding he did business in line with widely used practices at the time, and added, "The goal of this thing that's started by [[Belgrade]] is to smear my reputation in front of my business partners in [[Serbia]] and the rest of [[Europe]], but I'm not the main target. This will turn into one more attack on [[Montenegro]] by those that are pathologically obsessed with its independence, like they were with [[Zoran Đinđić|Đinđić]] all until his death." Subotić accused Montenegrin opposition leader [[Nebojša Medojević]] of insinuations and of "writing newspaper columns that helped create the atmosphere for the murder of Zoran Đinđić". Subotić concluded by saying: "Medojević and [[Vojislav Koštunica]] are working on the satanization of the Montenegrin state by creating an impression of its supposed criminalization".{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2007&mm=06&dd=26&nav_id=252762|title=Subotić: Nisam švercovao cigarete|website=B92.net|date=26 June 2007|accessdate=16 January 2016}} ===2008 arrest and two-month detention in Moscow=== On 28 April 2008, Subotić was arrested in [[Moscow]] at [[Sheremetyevo International Airport]] based on an [[Interpol]] red notice warrant issued against him by the Serbian police.{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.rs/hronika.php?id=39776|title=Cane uhapšen u Moskvi|website=Blic.rs|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=16 January 2016}} Though initially it looked like he'd be transferred to native [[Serbia]] where he's indicted on smuggling and tax fraud charges, and despite the fact that Serbian authorities sent an official extradition request for him to Russia, the Russian authorities let him go free on 27 June 2008.[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/world/text.php?vest=101454] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709015514/http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/world/text.php?vest=101454 |date=9 July 2008 }} ===B92 Interview, 16 March 2010=== Subotić accused [[Nebojša Medojević]], the [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] party leader of [[Movement for Change]] of having organized a manhunt on him on the orders of [[Serbia]]n businessman [[Milan Beko]] and Delta Holding owner Miroslav Mišković after they stole 50 million from Subotić to buy [[Port of Belgrade]] and daily newspaper [[Večernje Novosti]]. Medojević had claimed that Subotić and Darko Šarić had been hiding in a Montenegrin police villa in [[Žabljak]], while Subotić claimed in an interview that he was in [[Geneva, Switzerland]].[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2010&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=65829] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221052039/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2010&mm=03&dd=16&nav_id=65829 |date=21 December 2013 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.futuraplus.rs/ Futura Plus] *[http://www.louismax.com/ Louis Max] *[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/region.php?yyyy=2007&mm=03&dd=28&nav_id=238783 Cane Subotić gradi hotel u C. Gori], B92.net, 28 March 2007 *[http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2007&mm=06&dd=06&nav_category=120&nav_id=250127 Prva hapšenja u aferi "Mreža"], B92.net, 6 June 2007 *[https://archive.is/20140519191724/http://www.politika.rs/detaljno.php?nid=31495&lang=2 Raspisana poternica za Subotićem], Politika.rs, 15 June 2007 {{DEFAULTSORT:Subotic, Stanko}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Ub, Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]]

{{Infobox book | name = The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels | image = File:The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels.jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Alex Epstein (American writer)|Alex Epstein]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Fossil fuel]]s | genre = | publisher = Portfolio Hardcover | release_date = November 13, 2014 | media_type = Print | pages = 256 pages | isbn = 978-1591847441 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= 892514394 }}
'''''The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels''''' is a 2014 book by [[United States|American]] energy theorist [[Alex Epstein (American writer)|Alex Epstein]],<ref name=wsj>{{cite web|last1=Broughton|first1=Philip Delves|title=Making ‘The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels’|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/book-review-the-moral-case-for-fossil-fuels-by-alex-epstein-1417477909|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> in which the author argues that, although sometimes labeled as "immoral," the use of [[fossil fuel]]<nowiki/>s dramatically improves the overall progress of humanity, and improves life expectancy and income.<ref name=wsj/> The book was a ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' and ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' bestseller.<ref name=nyt>{{cite web|title=Best Selling Science Books|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/16/science/best-selling-science-books.html?_r=1|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bicmagazine.com/industry-segments/drilling-exploration-subsection/author-epstein-makes-the-moral-case-for-fossil-fuels/ |title=Author Epstein makes the moral case for fossil fuels |author=White, Andrew |website=BICMagazine.com |accessdate=October 15, 2017}}</ref>
==Overview== ''The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels'' outlines the benefits that the development of coal, oil, and natural gas have had on mankind, including improved health, increased lifespan, and expansion of material welfare.<ref name=bloomberg>{{cite web|title=Making the Case for the Benefits of Fossil Fuels|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2014-11-17/making-the-case-for-the-benefits-of-fossil-fuels|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref><ref name=fox>{{cite web|last1=Stossel|first1=John|title=Fossil fuels are no catastrophe. They have made our lives better|url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2014/12/10/fossil-fuels-are-no-catastrophe-have-made-our-lives-better/|publisher=Fox News Channel}}</ref>
The book also covers the topics of climate livability, the effects of [[carbon emissions]], the nature of the environmental movement, and the role fossil fuels play in everyday life.<ref name=cspan>{{cite web|last1=Edward Hilboldt|first1=John|title=Book Discussion on The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?322718-1/book-discussion-moral-case-fossil-fuels|publisher=CSPAN}}</ref><ref name=financialpost>{{cite web|last1=Foster|first1=Peter|title=Peter Foster: Don’t trust the global warming doomsters and their moral outrage|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2015/01/29/peter-foster-why-you-cant-trust-the-global-warming-doomsters/|work=Financial Post}}</ref> Epstein writes that alternative energy sources like wind, solar, and [[biofuel]]<nowiki/>s are inferior to fossil fuels because they are more expensive and less reliable.<ref name=blaze>Veer, PeerGuy [http://www.theblaze.com/contributions/the-moral-case-for-fossil-fuels-a-bold-humanist-statement/ The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels: A Bold Humanist Statement] ''The Blaze''. February 9, 2015</ref> He also examines trends in storm energy, global temperatures, and sea level changes and concludes that any changes are minor and do not justify alarmist predictions.<ref>Evans, Andrew [http://freebeacon.com/culture/burn-baby-burn/ Burn Baby Burn] ''The Washington Free Beacon''. February 9, 2015</ref>
==Reception== Positive reviews of the book were published by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',<ref name="wsj"/> ''[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barrons.com/articles/the-polymath-entrepreneur-1420261673 |title=The Polymath Entrepreneur |author=Epstein, Gene |website=Barrons.com |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> ''[[National Review]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/392503/fossil-fuels-and-morality-robert-zubrin |title=Fossil Fuels and Morality |author=Zubrin, Robert |website=NationalReview.com |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/archives/2015/01/16/energy-equity-vs-climate-moralizing/ |title=Fight Poverty—Use Fossil Fuels |author=Bailey, Ronald |website=Reason.com |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freebeacon.com/culture/burn-baby-burn/ |title=Burn Baby Burn |author= Evans, Andrew |website=FreeBeacon.com |accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref> and ''[[The Morning Sun (Pittsburg)|The Morning Sun]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themorningsun.com/opinion/20141210/walker-the-moral-triumph-of-fossil-fuels |title=Walker: The Moral Triumph of Fossil Fuels |author=Walker, Bruce Edward |website=TheMorningSun.com |accessdate= July 1, 2017}}</ref> Several blogs also featured positive reviews,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wmbriggs.com/post/13701/ |title=''The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels'' Reviewed |author=Briggs, William M. |website=WMBriggs.com |accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.science-skeptical.de/energieerzeugung/the-moral-case-for-fossil-fuels-alex-epsteins-gegenrede-zur-paepstlichen-enzyklika/0014228/ |title=The Moral Case For Fossil Fuels - Alex Epstein's Rebuttal to the Papal Encyclical |author=Heller, Peter |website=Science-Skeptical.de |accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.masterresource.org/fossil-fuel-utility/fossil-fuel-manifesto-proud/ |title=Fossil Fuels Industries: Time to Stand Tall! (book review of Alex Epstein's The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels) |author=Connors, Erin |website=MasterResource.com |accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.contrepoints.org/2014/11/14/188103-energies-fossiles-un-choix-humaniste-et-audacieux |title=Fossil Energy: A Humanistic and Daring Choice |author=Veer, Pierre-Guy |website=ContrePoints.org |accessdate= July 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ricochet.com/archives/fuel-humanity/ |title=Fuel For Humanity |author=Meyer, Tom |website=Ricochet.com |accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref> including those of the [[Independent Institute]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.independent.org/2015/09/29/fossil-fuels-are-the-lifeblood-of-modern-civilization/ |title=Fossil Fuels Are the Lifeblood of Modern Civilization |author=Tao, Aaron |website = Independent.org |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> and [[The Heartland Institute]],<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://blog.heartland.org/2015/01/book-review-the-moral-case-for-fossil-fuels/ |title=Book Review: The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels |author=Lehr, Jay |website=Heartland.org |accessdate= July 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://carbon-sense.com/2014/11/25/using-coal-oil-and-gas-the-moral-choice/ |title=Using coal, oil, and gas, the moral choice |author=Burnett, H. Sterling |website = Carbon-Sense.com |accessdate= July 1, 2017}}</ref> two conservative think tanks.
Critical reviews were published by ''[[Inside Higher Ed]]'',<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/technology-and-learning/boom-and-moral-case-fossil-fuels%25E2%2580%2599 |title=Higher Education Blogs {{!}} Blog U |website=''[[Inside Higher Ed]]'' |access-date=April 19, 2016}}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/edward-flattau/fossil-fuel-immorality_b_6342962.html |title=Fossil Fuel Immorality |date=December 17, 2014 |website=''[[The Huffington Post]]'' |access-date=April 19, 2016}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'',<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/oct/23/there-is-no-moral-case-for-coal-in-australia-just-an-imported-pr-line |title=There is no 'moral case for coal' in Australia, just an imported PR line |date=October 22, 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |issn=0261-3077 |access-date=April 19, 2016}}</ref> and ''Our World'', a publication of the [[United Nations University]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ourworld.unu.edu/en/review-the-moral-case-for-fossil-fuels-really |title=Review: "The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels" — Really? - Our World|website=ourworld.unu.edu |access-date=April 19, 2016}}</ref> Jason Wilson of ''The Guardian'' alleged that Epstein has a close association with conservative advocacy groups and receives funding from the [[Koch family |Koch brothers]] and that "Epstein's work has been popular and influential on the right because it is a particularly fluent, elaborate form of [[Climate change denial |climate denialism]]."<ref name=":2"/>
In 2014, Epstein was interviewed by [[Peter Thiel]] at an event hosted by the energy startup Tachyus. Thiel also provided a blurb for the book.<ref>[http://industrialprogress.com/2014/11/25/the-moral-case-rising/ The Moral Case Rising] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209211642/http://industrialprogress.com/2014/11/25/the-moral-case-rising/ |date=2015-02-09 }} “Center for Industrial Progress”. January 16, 2014</ref>
In December 2014, political commentator [[John McLaughlin (host)|John McLaughlin]] called Epstein "most original thinker of the year" for his book during McLaughlin's yearly ''[[The McLaughlin Group]]'' roundup.<ref>{{cite web|title=The McLaughlin Group 12/26/14|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BW-gLEpyjGY&feature=youtu.be}}</ref>

{{For|the [[Wikimedia Foundation]]'s policy on its own trademarks|wmf:Trademark policy}} {{For|the guideline on editing Wikipedia regarding trademarks|Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Trademarks}} {{Globalize/US|date=December 2010}}
{{Intellectual property}} '''Trademark infringement''' is a violation of the [[exclusive right]]s attached to a [[trademark]] without the authorization of the trademark owner or any licensees (provided that such authorization was within the scope of the licence). Infringement may occur when one party, the "infringer", uses a trademark which is identical or [[confusing similarity|confusingly similar]] to a trademark owned by another party, in relation to products or services which are identical or similar to the products or services which the registration covers. An owner of a trademark may commence civil [[lawsuit|legal proceedings]] against a party which infringes its registered trademark. In the United States, the [[Trademark Counterfeiting Act of 1984]] criminalized the intentional trade in counterfeit goods and services.<ref>Irina D. Manta Spring 2011 [http://jolt.law.harvard.edu/articles/pdf/v24/24HarvJLTech469.pdf The Puzzle of Criminal Sanctions for Intellectual Property Infringement] Harvard Journal of Law & Technology 24(2):469-518</ref>{{rp|485–486}}
If the respective marks and products or services are entirely dissimilar, trademark infringement may still be established if the registered mark is well known pursuant to the [[Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property|Paris Convention]]. In the United States, a cause of action for use of a mark for such dissimilar services is called [[trademark dilution]].
In some jurisdictions a party other than the owner (e.g., a licensee) may be able to pursue trademark infringement proceedings against an infringer if the owner fails to do so.
== Factors == Courts consider various factors in order to determine whether a trademark was infringed.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-10-30|title=Rescuecom Corp. v. Google Inc.|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Rescuecom_Corp._v._Google_Inc.&oldid=807804980|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://h2o.law.harvard.edu/collages/13859|title=Rescuecom Corp. v. Google Inc.|website=h2o.law.harvard.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref> * Whether the plaintiff has a valid trademark. A trademark can be valid because it is officially registered, or because it has a claim under common law. * Whether the trademark is being used by the defendant. * Whether the defendant's use of the mark is "in commerce." * Whether that use is connected to the sale, offer, distribution, or advertising of a product. * Whether the defendant's use of the trademark is likely to confuse consumers. This last factor, consumer confusion, is the main topic of debate in most cases.
=== Consumer Confusion === Where the respective marks or products or services are not identical, similarity will generally be assessed by reference to whether there is a '''likelihood of confusion''' that consumers will believe the products or services originated from the trademark owner.
Likelihood of confusion is not necessarily measured by actual [[consumer confusion]] if two products do not directly compete against each other but are in proximate markets. Then, to determine consumer confusion, a court may apply one of various factor tests. The primary test comes from [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] and is found in ''AMF, Inc v. Sleekcraft Boats'', 599 F.2d 341 (C.A.9) 1979.<ref name=":0" /> The Court there announced eight specific elements to measure likelihood of confusion: # Strength of the mark # Proximity of the goods # Similarity of the marks # Evidence of actual confusion # Marketing channels used # Type of goods and the degree of care likely to be exercised by the purchaser # Defendant's intent in selecting the mark # Likelihood of expansion of the product lines<ref name=":0">[http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/metaschool/fisher/domain/tmcases/amf.htm AMF, Inc v Sleekcraft Boats, 599 F.2d 341 (C.A.9) 1979]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www3.ce9.uscourts.gov/jury-instructions/node/244|title=15.18 Infringement—Likelihood of Confusion—Factors—Sleekcraft Test {{!}} Model Jury Instructions|website=www3.ce9.uscourts.gov|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cyber.harvard.edu/metaschool/fisher/domain/tm.htm|title=Overview of Trademark Law|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cyber.harvard.edu/metaschool/fisher/domain/tmcases/polaroid.htm|title=Polaroid Corp. v. Polarad Elect. Corp., 287 F.2d 492 (2d Cir.), cert. denied, 368 U.S. 820 (1961).|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
Other Courts have fashioned their own tests for likelihood of confusion—like those announced in ''In re E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co''., 476 F.2d 1357, 177 USPQ 563 (CCPA 1973)'',''<ref>[https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-11th-circuit/1413742.html IN RE E.I. DuPONT DE NEMOURS & COMPANY-BENLATE LITIGATION], 476 F.2d 1357 (1996).</ref> known collectively as the [[United States trademark law|''DuPont'' factors]].
== Defenses == The party accused of infringement may be able to defeat infringement proceedings if it can establish a valid ''exception'' (e.g., comparative advertising) or ''defence'' (e.g., [[Laches (equity)|laches]]) to infringement, or attack and cancel the underlying registration (e.g., for non-use) upon which the proceedings are based. Other defenses include [[Genericide|genericness]], functionality, [[Abandonment of trademark|abandonment]], or [[Fair use (U.S. trademark law)|fair use]].
== Globally == The [[Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement|ACTA trade agreement]], signed in May 2011 by the United States, Japan, Switzerland, and the EU, requires that its parties add criminal penalties, including incarceration and fines, for copyright and trademark infringement, and obligated the parties to actively police for infringement.<ref name="Bitton">Miriam Bitton (2012) [http://www.law.northwestern.edu/jclc/backissues/v102/n1/1021_67.Bitton.pdf Rethinking the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement’s Criminal Copyright Enforcement Measures] The Journal of Criminal Law & Criminology 102(1):67-117</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ige.ch/fileadmin/user_upload/Juristische_Infos/e/transparency_paper.pdf|title=The Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement – Summary of Key Elements Under Discussion|date=November 6, 2009|work=transparency paper|publisher=Swiss federation of Intellectual Property|format=pdf|accessdate=June 8, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Xuan_p211">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bN3o1uwpKF4C&dq=copyright+infringement+international+acta&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Intellectual property enforcement: international perspectives|last=Correa|first=Carlos Maria|author2=Li, Xuan|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|year=2009|isbn=978-1-84844-663-2|pages=211}}</ref>
In many countries (but not in countries like the United States, which recognizes common law trademark rights), a trademark which is ''not'' registered cannot be "infringed" as such, and the trademark owner cannot bring infringement proceedings. Instead, the owner may be able to commence proceedings under the common law for [[passing off]] or [[misrepresentation]], or under legislation which prohibits [[unfair business practices]]. In some jurisdictions, infringement of [[trade dress]] may also be actionable.
== Notable cases == * ''[[Facebook, Inc. v. Power Ventures, Inc.]]'', case still pending * ''[[Google, Inc. v. American Blind & Wallpaper Factory, Inc.]]'', in which Google's AdWords program was alleged to be in violation of trademark * ''[[Rescuecom Corp. v. Google Inc.]]'', in which the use of trademarks in Google's AdWords program was found to be a "use in commerce" under the Lanham Act * ''[[Network Automation, Inc. v. Advanced Systems Concepts, Inc.]]'', in which the use of a competitor's trademark as an Internet advertisement search keyword was found to not constitute trademark infringement * ''[[College Network, Inc. v. Moore Educational Publishers, Inc.]]'', in which the use of a competitor's trademark does not qualify as a "use in commerce" is upheld * ''[[Polaroid Corp. v. Polarad Elects.]]''
== See also == * [[Madrid Protocol]] * [[Canadian trademark law]] * [[Exhaustion of rights]] * [[Passing off]] * [[Trade dress]] * [[Patent infringement]] * [[Copyright infringement]]

Must Pay $143 Million to Trovan Ltd. in Largest Trademark Judgement Ever Awarded in the United States] * [http://www.uspto.gov/web/offices/tac/tmlaw2.html#_Toc52344333 Section 43(a) of the Lanham Act (15 U.S.C. 1125(a))] * [http://www.ipo.gov.uk/t-law.htm The Trade Mark Act (UK)] * [http://aisel.aisnet.org/cais/vol27/iss1/6 Study of Alleged Trademark Infringement Against Global Brands in Internet Search Advertising]

{{Infobox company | name = Vornado Air, LLC | logo = File:VORNADO aaa-v-logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = Vornado logo as of 2015 | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = en | former_name = Vornadofan, O. A. Sutton Company | type = limited liability company | industry = manufacturing | founded = <!-- if known: {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[country]] --> | founders = Ralph K. Odor (1945), Ottis A. Sutton (1945), Michael Coup (1990) | hq_location = | hq_location_city = Andover, Kansas | hq_location_country = United States | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = fans and household appliances | brands = Vornado, Vornadofan | services = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | ratio = <!-- for BANKS ONLY --> | rating = <!-- for BANKS ONLY --> | website = http://www.vornado.com/ }} '''Vornado''' is a US firm based in [[Andover, Kansas]], that designs and manufactures household fans and other small appliances related to air circulation.<ref name="expansion">{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/wichita/print-edition/2011/12/02/vornado-expanding-headquarters-with.html |title=Vornado expanding headquarters with $1M warehouse addition |publisher=Wichita Business Journal |date=2 December 2011 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> The current incarnation of the company was founded in 1989, two years after the death of Ralph K. Odor (1895-1987), who founded the firm in the 1930s with Ottis A. Sutton in [[Wichita, Kansas]].<ref>http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/vornado-realty-trust-history/</ref> In fact, the name of the company is a [[portmanteau]] of "Vortex" and "Tornado".
==History== [[File:Vornado.jpg|thumb|A vintage model from the 1940s or 1950s]] Ralph K. Odor experimented with different designs to improve [[propeller (aircraft)|airplane propeller]]s in the late 1920s. In the 1930s, Odor met Ottis A. Sutton and the two men continued to experiment with different designs for propellers and were granted several patents. Odor and Sutton realized the propeller designs could also be applied to household fans, and after the end of [[World War II]], the '''O.A. Sutton Corporation''' began marketing Vornado fans under the ''Vornadofan'' brandname.<ref name="about_us_vornado_com">{{cite web|last=|first=|date=|url=http://www.vornado.com/about-vornado/AboutUs.aspx|title=About Us|publisher=Vornado Air LLC|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="company_history">[https://www.vornado.com/history "Our history of making history,"] official website, Vornado Air, LLC, retrieved June 23, 2017.</ref>
Early fans were designed by industrial designer Richard Ten Eyck.<ref name="teneyck">{{cite web|last=|first=|date=|url=http://www.artic.edu/research/richard-ten-eyck-1920-2009|title=Richard Ten Eyck|publisher=[[Art Institute of Chicago]]|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref>, and were distinguished from ordinary fans by enclosure in a short duct shaped as [[aerodynamics|aerodynamically]] contoured cylindrical ring, with an added concentric flared intake duct ring, sharply pitched blades, stationary [[vanes]] and aerodynamic [[grille]], and rubber [[shock-mount]]ing; the design was advertised as making the fan exceptionally quiet, efficient and effective, delivering a narrower, more-concentrated blast of air than normal fans.<ref name="company_history" /><ref name="company_faqs">[https://www.vornado.com/faqs "FAQs,"] official website, Vornado Air, LLC, retrieved June 23, 2017.</ref>
The company later added a line of air conditioners.
Amid sales that had fallen to half of its peak, the company ceased production in September 1958 and began liquidating its inventory, and manufacturing and office equipment were auctioned off in June 1959.<ref name="tihen">{{cite web|last=|first=|date=|url=http://specialcollections.wichita.edu/collections/local_history/tihen/pdf/eagle/Eag1959.pdf|title=Tihen Notes from 1959 Wichita Eagle|publisher=Department of Special Collections, Wichita State University Libraries|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref> Sutton's air conditioner coil manufacturing line was purchased by '''Gibson Refrigerator Co.''' and moved from Wichita.<ref name="gibson">{{cite web|last=|first=|date=August 1959|url=http://specialcollections.wichita.edu/collections/local_history/tihen/pdf/eagle/Eag1959.pdf|title=Briefly Stated|publisher=''Air Conditioning, Heating and Ventilating''|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref> In October 1959, the O.A. Sutton Corp. was purchased by the discount department store chain '''[[Two Guys]],''' which subsequently renamed itself '''Vornado, Inc.'''<ref name=Vornado_history>{{cite web |title=Vornado Realty Trust |url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Vornado-Realty-Trust-Company-History.html |accessdate=August 31, 2014 |work=FundingUniverse |date=<!--undated--> |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
The consolidated company expanded the Vornado line of appliances to more than 50 in under three years, including ranges, freezers, hair dryers, and [[Can opener|electronic can openers]] sold by the Two Guys chain as well as other dealers, though the manufacturing operations were [[Outsourcing|outsourced]].<ref name=Vornado_history /> That company eventually divested all retail operations and evolved into what is now '''[[Vornado Realty Trust]],''' a [[real estate investment trust]].
==Current== The Vornado brand name was resurrected in 1989 by Michael Coup. Operating under the name '''Vornado Air Circulation Systems Inc.,''' Coup obtained the rights to the Vornado trademark and worked with original designer Richard Ten Eyck to come up with a new fan design.<ref name="newvornado">{{cite web|last=Siebenmark|first=Jerry|date=February 23, 2003|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/wichita/stories/2003/02/24/story7.html|title=Making 'good stuff' that lasts is what pleases Vornado's Michael Coup|publisher=''Wichita Business Journal''|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref> Initially the company operated in northeast Wichita (Vornado's original hometown).
Between January 1989 and August 1990, Vornado sold about 135,000 of its fans with a distinctive spiral [[grille]]. In August 1990, competitor Duracraft began offering a cheaper, visually similar fan, and by November 1992, Duracraft had sold nearly one million of them -- that company's second-largest-selling household fan. Vornado sued under the [[Lanham Act]] claiming deceptive imitation in appearance -- but an appeals court ruled against Vornado, because the design had been a part of their expired patent, and was now in the [[public domain]].<ref name="appeal_vorndao_v_duracraft">[https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/USCOURTS-ca10-94-03191/pdf/USCOURTS-ca10-94-03191-0.pdf "VORNADO AIR CIRCULATION SYSTEMS INC v. DURACRAFT CORPORATION"], No. 94–3191, Decided: July 05, 1995, United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit, also [https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-10th-circuit/1198562.html posted at Findlaw.com], retrieved June 23, 2017</ref>
According to the U.S. [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] (CPSC), from January 1993 through February 2004, Vornado received over 300 reports of defective heater units overheating, melting, smoking, or catching fire. The CPSC alleged that Vornado Air Circulation Systems, Inc., failed to promptly report these incidents to the CPSC as required by law, saying Vornado only reported the incidents to the CPSC after CPSC staff started asking questions, in February, 2004. <ref name="vornado_trust_to_pay_cpsc">[https://www.cpsc.gov/Newsroom/News-Releases/2008/Vornado-Trust-to-Pay-500000-Civil-Penalty-for-Failure-to-Report-Defects-and-Hazards-with-Electric-Heaters "Vornado Trust to Pay $500,000 Civil Penalty for Failure to Report Defects and Hazards with Electric Heaters,"], Release #08-180, January 31, 2008, U.S. [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]], retrieved June 26, 2017 {{PD-notice}}</ref>
In December 2006, Vornado Air Circulation Systems sold most of its assets to a private equity firm, which formed a new company, '''Vornado Air, LLC.''' , in Wichita's neighboring suburban community of [[Andover, Kansas]].<ref name="llc">{{cite web|last=|first=|date=February 5, 2008|url=https://www.cpsc.gov//PageFiles/96713/vornado.pdf|title=Consumer Product Safety Commission|publisher=Federal Register|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="vornado_vh110 recall_cpsc_gov">[https://www.cpsc.gov/recalls/2014/vornado-air-recalls-electric-space-heaters "Vornado Air Recalls Electric Space Heaters Due to Fire and Burn Hazard,"] Recall #14-256, August 14, 2014, U.S. [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]], retrieved June 26, 2017</ref>
In January, 2008, the CPSC reported that a liquidating trust, acting on behalf of the by-now dissolved manufacturer, Vornado Air Circulation Systems, Inc. (formerly of Andover, Kansas), agreed to pay the government a $500,000 civil penalty, settling the prior CPSC allegations against Vornado Air Circulation Systems Inc., regarding the 300-plus unreported defective heater units. Vornado did not, however, concede any violation of law.<ref name="vornado_trust_to_pay_cpsc" />
On August 14, 2014, the [[Consumer Product Safety Commission|CPSC]] announced a recall of 79,000 Vornado-brand electric heaters (Vornado VH110 Whole Room Vortex electric space heaters) which had been made in China for Vornado Air, LLC, of [[Andover, Kansas]], and sold for about $60 at several major retail store chains and online sellers. The recall followed 29 reports of units overheating and melting, including seven reports of heaters catching fire, resulting in one report of smoke inhalation and one report of property damage caused by soot and smoke.<ref name="vornado_vh110 recall_cpsc_gov" />
==See also== *[[Vornado Realty Trust]], a realty company which shares the name due to its acquisition of the O.A. Sutton Company

{{EngvarB|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Yvonne Makolo | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Rwanda]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Information technology|IT Specialist]] & [[Business Executive]] | years_active = 1993 — present | nationality = Rwandan | ethnicity = | citizenship = Rwandan | residence = [[Kigali]], [[Rwanda]] | known_for = Business, management | networth = | home_town = | title = [[Managing Director]]
[[Rwandair]] | spouse = | religion = }} '''Yvonne Manzi Makolo''' is a Rwandan [[Information technology|IT specialist]] and [[business executive]], who serves as the [[managing director]] and [[chief executive officer]] of [[Rwandair]], the national airline of [[Rwanda]]. She was appointed to that position on 6 April 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.newtimes.co.rw/rwanda/makolo-appointed-new-ceo-rwandair |title=Rwanda: Makolo Appointed New CEO of Rwandair | newspaper=[[The New Times (Rwanda)]] |author=Times Reporter | access-date=9 April 2018 |location=Kigali |date=6 April 2018}} Prior to that, she served as the Deputy CEO responsible for corporate affairs at the same airline, from April 2017 until April 2018.{{cite web| url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/RwandAir-boss-dropped/2560-3879788-ermpsuz/index.html |title=RwandAir boss dropped |date=6 April 2016 |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] | access-date=9 April 2018 | first=Edmund |last=Kagire | location=Nairobi}} ==Background and education== Yvonne was born in Rwanda. In 1993, she voluntarily migrated to [[Canada]]. Ten years later, in 2003 she returned to her native Rwanda. She and her older sister were raised by a single mother, Yvonne's father having died when the daughters were very small. She has specialized training in [[information technology]] and has worked as a [[software developer]], both in Canada and Rwanda.{{cite web|access-date=9 April 2018 | url=http://www.newtimes.co.rw/section/read/203994 |title=Women can do what men can and sometimes even better, says MTN’s Yvonne Makolo |date=29 September 2016 |newspaper=[[The New Times (Rwanda)]] |first=Nasra |last=Bishumba |location=Kigali}} ==Career== In 2006, she joined [[MTN Group|MTN Rwanda]], a leading telecommunications service provider in the country. Over time, she rose through the ranks to the position of [[Chief Marketing Officer]] (CMO) and also concurrently served as the [[Chief Executive Officer]] (CEO), in an acting capacity. In April 2017, when the [[Cabinet of Rwanda]] made management changes at Rwandair, Yvonne Manzi Makolo was appointed Deputy CEO, responsible for Corporate Affairs. One year later, in another managerial change at the national airline, she was appointed to the position of Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer at Rwandair. ==Other responsibilities== Yvonne Makolo is a mother of young children. ==See also== * [[Transport in Rwanda]] * [[List of airports in Rwanda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.rwandair.com/ Website of Rwandair] * [http://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/kagame-appoints-new-ministers Kagame appoints new ministers] As of 6 April 2018. {{DEFAULTSORT:Makolo, Yvonne}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Rwandan businesspeople]] [[Category:Rwandan business executives]] [[Category:Women chief executives]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]] [[Category:Rwandan women in business]]

[[Order of Friendship]] (2010)World Economic Forum’s Business Statesman Award (2016){{cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/press/2016/10/world-economic-forum-announces-inaugural-business-statesman-award/ |title=World Economic Forum Announces Inaugural Business Statesman Award|website=World Economic Forum|accessdate=7 July 2018}} | website = https://www.enka.com }} '''Şarık Tara''' (22 April 1930 – 28 June 2018) was a Turkish billionaire who founded [[Enka İnşaat ve Sanayi A.Ş.]], Turkey's largest construction company, with [[Sadi Gülçelik]], in 1957.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/opinion/jale-ozgenturk/turkish-business-mogul-sarik-tara-dies-at-88-133983|title=Turkish business mogul Şarık Tara dies at 88|website=Hürriyet Daily News|accessdate=30 June 2018}} As well as being an international engineer, contractor, industrialist, he was known for his philanthropy. ==Personal life == === Early life and education=== Tara was born in what is now the [[Republic of Macedonia]] but emigrated with his family to Turkey in 1942 when he was 12 due to [[World War II]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/sarik-tara/|title=Sarik Tara|website=forbes.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}} His father Fevzija Hadžihamzić, an ethnic [[Bosniak]], was from [[Priboj]] in the [[Sandžak]] region of [[Serbia]]. Upon arrival to Turkey, his father changed their surname to Tara, in reference to river [[Tara (Drina)|Tara]] which flows mainly through Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro. The family's extremely reduced circumstances required Tara to start working when he was young. His knowledge of foreign languages help him secure night work as a translator at a textile factory while he was still attending Şişli Terakki high school.{{cite web|url= https://www.yeniakit.com.tr/kimdir/%C5%9Ear%C4%B1k_Tara |title=Sarik Tara|website=yeniakit.com|accessdate=5 July 2018}} Tara graduated with a degree in Civil Engineering from Istanbul Technical University in 1954.{{cite web|url= https://ins.itu.edu.tr/hakkimizda/mezunlarimiz/sarik-tara |title=Sarik Tara|website= ins.itu.edu.tr |accessdate=5 July 2018}} ===Marriage and Children=== Tara married Lale Ataman in 1956. The couple has three children, seven grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Tara's son M. Sinan Tara is currently ENKA's Executive Chairman of the Board of Directors. Tara's grandson, A. Mehmet Tara, is currently ENKA's President and Chairman of the Executive Committee. {{cite web|url= https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/company-officers/ENKAI.IS |title= ENKA Insaat ve Sanayi AS (ENKAI.IS) |website= Reuters.com|accessdate=5 July 2018}} ==Career== ===Business=== Between 1954 and 1957, Tara worked as a site manager on various construction projects. In 1957, with his brother-in-law, [[Sadi Gülçelik]], he established ENKA contracting company. Today [[Enka İnşaat ve Sanayi A.Ş.]] is a global company in the construction sector with large scale road, tunnel, power plant, and real estate projects. To date, it has completed 396 projects in 45 countries with a total contract value of 40 billion USD. Domestically, it has completed 124 projects in Turkey with a total contract value of 7 billion USD. {{cite web|url= https://www.enka.com/allfiles/pdf/ENKAI_ANNUAL_REPORT_31122017.pdf |title=ENKA Annual Report 2017|website= ENKA Insaat ve Sanayi AS |accessdate=5 July 2018}} ENKA is also known for constructing U.S. embassy buildings; 36% ($887 million) of ENKA's revenue during the first nine months of 2017 came from the construction of U.S. embassy buildings in various countries. The conglomerate is one Turkey's largest electricity producers, and is expanding in the energy sector. Over half of ENKA's approximately $3.5 billion in annual revenue comes from energy production. It is Turkey's leading private electricity producer. From 1984 onwards, Tara played a pioneering role in Turkey entering the Soviet Union. In 1988, Tara signed the contracts for ENKA's renovation of the Petrovski Arcade and construction of the Moscow Hospital. ENKA currently owns offices, a hotel, and 11 shopping malls across Russia. Tara also paved the way for other Turkish companies to become successful in Russia. ===International Relations=== After Tara's first participation in the World Economic Forum in Davos in 1973, he became a regular. Tara is considered a catalyst in developing Turkey's international relations and presence in the 1970s and 80s. Tara advocated for increased dialogue and commerce between Greece and Turkey. During the World Economic Forum in Davos in 1988, Tara was instrumental in the meeting between prime ministers Turgut Özal and Andreas Papandreou, resulting in the establishment of an official bilateral dialogue between the two countries {{cite web|url= http://altayatli.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Atli_dissertation-copy.pdf |title= Business Associations and Foreign Policy: Revisiting Statebusiness Relations in Turkey |website= altayatli.com |accessdate=5 July 2018}} and Tara becoming the chair of the Turkish-Greek Business Council. Tara remained in this role until 2004. His role in establishing increased cooperation between the respective business communities earned him the first and only Business Statesman Award from the World Economic Forum in 2016.
Tara was active in the foundation of Turkey's Foreign Economic Relations Board (DEİK) in 1986, becoming a member of its executive board. The same year, Tara chaired the Turkish-Japanese Business Council, which was established within DEIK in the same year. He remained in this position until 2000. Tara lobbied for Turkey's accession to the European Union for many years, as well as for promoting regional peace in the Balkans. ===Philanthropic Works=== In 1983, Şarık Tara established the 33,600m2 Sadi Gülçelik Sports Complex located in Istinye, Istanbul, named in honor of his deceased brother-in-law and business partner. This facility was designed to support education, the arts, and sports. To guarantee the future of this facility, Tara established the ENKA Foundation the same year.{{cite web|url= https://www.enka.com/sustainability/home/society/enka-foundation/ |title= ENKA Foundation |website=ENKA|accessdate=7 July 2018}} ====Schools==== [[ENKA Schools]] opened their doors in 1996. In 1999, Adapazarı ENKA School was established, immediately after the Adapazarı earthquake of 1999. The quick construction enabled teaching to begin in the same year. Adapazarı ENKA School provides free scholarships and housing. The Kocaeli ENKA Anatolian Technical and Vocational High School was established in 2008. ==== The Arts==== ENKA Culture Arts foundation facilities within the Sadi Gülçelik Sports Complex includes the ENKA Eşref Denizhan Open Air Theater, which seats 1,000; the ENKA Auditorium, which seats 600; and the ENKA Dr. Clinton Vickers Art Gallery, all of which host events that are open to the general public.{{cite web|url=https://www.enkasanat.org/mekanlar/|title= Mekanlar |website= ENKA Sanat |accessdate=7 July 2018}} ====Sports==== The ENKA foundation's sports complex trains athletes for national and international competition in the following sports: Track and Field, Tennis, Swimming, Water Polo, Volleyball, Basketball, Triathlon, Skiing. Established in 1983, the club is currently composed of 1,087 licensed athletes and 79 professional trainers. ENKA Sports Club had 22 of its athletes compete in the 2016 Rio Olympics and 17 in the 2012 London Olympics.{{cite web|url= http://www.aljazeera.com.tr/haber/olimpiyata-en-cok-sporcu-gonderen-kulup-enka |title= Olimpiyata en çok sporcu gönderen kulüp: ENKA |website=Al Jazeera|accessdate=5 July 2018}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tara, Sarik}} [[Category:Turkish civil engineers]] [[Category:Turkish businesspeople]] [[Category:Turkish philanthropists]] [[Category:Turkish people of Bosniak descent]] [[Category:People from Skopje]] [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Yugoslav emigrants to Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish billionaires]]
